titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I begin upon this Volume with the record of yesterday. See Vol. 9. for the last preceding date
25. IV. Wednesday. Sun rose 4:42. last Solstitial day. Ride and Swim— Fahrenheit 90.

I sent for Coll. Bomford to speak with him of a man named Copeland, who was employed at the armoury at Harper’s ferry, and was dismissed for making frivolous and groundless charges against the Superintendent. He is now applying to me for other employment, and I sent to Coll. Bomford to enquire into the circumstances of his case. He said he had since his dismission employed him occasionally, and would again if opportunity should occur— But he was a bad tempered man, and he could not give him a permanent appointment because there was nobody in the public service willing to be associated with him. Coll. Bomford promised me some white mulberry-trees of which he has many from the seeds sown in the Summer of 1826— Coll. Jones the Adjutant General, brought over the Letter of General Scott to him, asking a leave of absence from his command for 20 days, and the answer— Scott’s Letter is private, and asks not a furlough to be announced in general orders, but this short leave of absence, which by order of the Secretary of War was granted. I told Coll. Jones, that I must ask for copies of both the Letters, because I should now limit the time of General Scott’s leave of absence, and it was therefore necessary to authenticate the time and manner of his obtaining it— General Scott was pursuing such a course that I thought it probable these Letters would all be published— He asked his leave of absence to visit his family who were about to embark for France— I told Coll. Jones that he might inform General Scott that I had required a copy of his Letter asking for the leave of absence— Mr Foy came to complain of Mr Elgar the Commissioner of the Public buildings, who proposes to reduce the width both of the border and of the gravel walk within the railing of the Capitol Square on the western side; which Mr Foy thinks will have a bad effect on the whole enclosure— He thinks Mr Elgar encroaches upon his domains and calls for my interposition. He spoke also of work to be done at the yard of this house; and I promised to see and advise with Mr Elgar— General Porter came with Major Delafield, and spoke of the disingenuous proceeding of Mr Barclay the British Commissioner under the seventh Article of the Treaty of Ghent— Major Delafield undertook with my assent to draw up a statement in reply to that part of Mr Barclay’s Report— It appears that both parties have abandoned Mitchell’s Map which is acknowledged to be incorrect of the topography of those regions— The adjourned Cabinet Meeting was held at one. Present Mr Rush, General Porter, and Mr Southard— General Porter had the draft of a Letter in answer to the last from General Scott— It varied a little, as we thought with improvement upon that which was proposed yesterday— In refusing the furlough which he asks till next April, it states that the reasons which he assigns for asking it are conclusive against its being granted— And adds that as the Order from the War Department granting him leave of absence was not limited in time, I had thought proper to fix the 25th. of July next as the term, and that I expected he would by that day have returned and resumed the Command of the Western division of the army. One or two slight modifications were necessary, which were pointed out; and with them
General Porter is to despatch the Letter this Evening— After the Meeting was over I had much conversation with Mr Rush upon the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, and with Mr Southard upon the proposed exploring Expedition. The By-Laws of the Corporation have been reported and adopted, and the Salary of the Officers is fixed— Mr Rush thought they might have dispensed with a Treasurer; but that was not agreed to. Mr Southard said he believed Captain Wadsworth would decline taking the command of the Expedition—and he was perplexed to find a substitute for him. There was much and I hope not useless discussion of various topics connected with the fitting out of the expedition— I visited the Garden before Riding and the Nursery afterwards with Mr Foy— The unknown trees are a Cane, A Button wood, a Plum, of peculiar character, and several grape-vines. The Evening was extremely sultry, and afterwards a rain gust with winds from the East.
26. IV. Thursday— Sun-rose 4:42— Ride and Swim— Fahrenheit 90.

There was a heavy shower of Rain in the Night, and this morning was fresh and cool. I swam 15 minutes in the Potowmac from the Rock, and rode to the Eastern branch Bridge; whence I returned round the Capitol Square in 29 minutes— I infer the distance 3 1/4 miles— The Sun came out soon after breakfast, and the heat for the remainder of the day and Evening was intense— Theodore Bainbridge newly appointed a Lieutenant in the Marine Corps, called, having just arrived to report himself to the Commandant of the Corps. Mr Mercer introduced a Mr William B Harrison, a revolutionary Officer residing in his District, who now solicits the appointment of keeper of the Penitentiary—an Officer not yet established by Law. Mr Harrison brought sundry recommendations and a printed Statement of his own dated at Soldier’s Repose, of all the Battles and Sieges of the Revolutionary War in which he bore a part. He has been familiar with the Penitentiaries of two or three of the States, and he thinks that the appointment of a Superintendent of the one now building here would be expedient now, though not yet provided for by Law. Dr Watkins told me there was an appointment of a Postmaster to be made at Maysville, Kentucky— That it was an exceedingly important Office, and unless care should be taken he was afraid the Postmaster General would appoint an inveterate enemy to the administration— Mr Gales the Mayor of the City read me a Letter from Charles Cutts late Secretary to the Senate stating his desperate condition, and intreating his influence to obtain for him the appointment of Navy Agent at Portsmouth— Mr Gales said the place was not suited to Mr Cutts; but that if Mr Decatur now the Navy Store-keeper could be appointed Agent, Cutts would be well-suited to take his place as Store-keeper— Gales said that Cutts’s removal from the Office of Secretary to the Senate, was a trick of Van Buren’s, and that he was a better Secretary than the one they have now— I said there had been some unfortunate rumours respecting the habits of Mr Cutts— Gales said there had been some foundation for them; but that for two years before his displacement from the Senate, he had reformed. This day there was a great public dinner given by the Citizens of Georgetown to Mr Mercer to which I was invited; but on the established usage declined attending. Abigail S. Adams painted my Seedling pot N. 1. with the Tamarind, and Persimon growing in it— The seed lobes of the Tamarind, have this day fallen from the tree, now just one month up. They had shrunk up almost to nothing— I planted one Persimon seed and 1. Yard Cherry Stone in Box N. 4. and 1. Persimon seed at the Centre of Pot N. 5 surrounded by a Circle of dry Strawberry seeds.
27. IV. Friday. Sun rose 4:43. Garden— Boat-Bath. Fahrenheit 90.

Mr Southard brought several recommendations in favour of George Long as Navy Agent at Portsmouth New-Hampshire— He said Mr Long himself was here, and had sundry good reasons for claiming the preference for himself. But as I had given the direction for the appointment of J. N. Sherburne before Mr Long’s claim appeared, I saw no sufficient cause for changing that determination— Mr Southard proposed to employ Mr Reynolds, to visit Nantucket before the exploring expedition shall be fitted out, to obtain there and report all the preliminary information which can be acquired from the Navigators of that place who have frequented the Southern Ocean in whaling ships, and which Mr Southard expects will be considerable and very useful. To this I agreed. The expense to be defrayed in the first instance from the Contingent fund of the Navy Department; but I advised that an Account should be opened with the Expedition to which ultimately every expense incident to it should be charged, so that those which may be incurred before the next Session of Congress, may be included in the estimates for the ensuing year— Edward Wyer brought me some Pacane Nuts, which he said must be sowed the next Month, which I suppose is a mistake. Mr Long brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr B. Gorham, the member of Congress from Boston. He set forth all his claims to the Navy Agency at Portsmouth— His father was a distinguished member of Congress during and after our Revolution. He himself was an Officer in the army through the whole Revolutionary War—and an owner of privateers during the last War with Great-Britain— He had also something to say against Mr Sherburne— I told him I hoped some occasion might occur hereafter, when I should have it in my power to serve him— Mr Brent was here with a draft of a Letter from him to T. M. Rodney, commercial Agent at the Havanna, but now at Wilmington Delaware. I suggested some modification of the Letter, with which is to be enclosed a copy of an anonymous Letter to Mr Clay, containing charges against Rodney— Mr Brent brought also several Recommendations of a Mr Owen, for the appointment of Commercial at Principe in the Island of Cuba; to whom I directed that a Commission should issue. Mr La Vergne of Louisiana was here. His Negotiation for a Loan at New-York, for the use of a Bank at New-Orleans has failed, by disagreement about the terms—but he has been advised to make the experiment at London, and is about to embark for England— His companion young Villeré became homesick and returned to New-Orleans— I sent for Mr Elgar, and spoke to him of Foy’s complaint, of Elgar’s intended contraction of the border and gravel walk round the enclosed iron railing, on the West side of the Capitol— Elgar mentioned to me his reasons for this contraction, which I thought not sufficient. He asked me to take at some time a view of the spot which I promised I would do— He said Mr Rufus King whose gardener Foy had been, and at whose recommendation he had been employed here had given him a high character as a Gardener, in every respect, except in the laying out of grounds. In that, he followed the fashion of a century back, without knowledge of modern improvements— I said he had laid out my Nursery much to my satisfaction; and I thought had a competent knowledge to lay out any grounds upon a small Scale— I visited the garden this morning— Planted in the Eastern seedling bed 1. Row of 36 whole Honey Cherries— Of this experiment I shall not witness the result— My last years pot raised Apple-tree at the North-east corner of the garden, after a check upon its vegetation of about 20 days and putting out four lateral twigs is now shooting up again—and is 22 inches tall. One apple of this years growth in the Eastern Seedling bed is 18 inches high, also taking a second shoot after a check— Tallest plum tree 31 inches. Peach 29.
In a box in the garden, where about the 24th. of May I planted 2 date Stones, and I forget what else, not minuted, I see a plant up this morning, but know not what it is—nor does Ouseley. The white mustard seed in the bed is 3 feet high and in full blossom. That in Box N. 5 is not half that size but one of its plants has blossomed—four small fawn coloured Petals—Tetrandria Monogynia— The Shagbark planted in Pot N. 2 has come up— I planted in Pot N. 5 round the Peach tree 13. fresh Orange-seeds— I had the Cherries picked from the bearing tree in the yard, to be sure of productive Stones. Visited the Nursery. No new Cork Oaks since the 16th.— Trespassing Cattle had been along the whole South border—trampled down several trees, and crop’d off the tops of others, especially some flourishing peaches Evening intensely warm—yet I wrote.
28. IV. Saturday— Sun rose 4:43. Boat-Bath— Capitol. Foy.

Visited the Garden— Found the tall plum tree 32 inches high. The tallest peach 30 inches—the wild cherry 19. inches—the tallest this years Apple tree 28. inches. The last years Pot apple 22 inches on the top of the stem of one of the Battle ground Oaks, a bud is formed looking as if it would open to a blossom— The unknown plant in the box unchanged since yesterday— The Coffee seeds unfolding into leaves, looking sickly— In the house a 6th. Tangier Orange came up in box N. 3. planted 15. May. a 2d. in Pot N. 4. planted 3. June—a 5th. in Box N. 4. planted 15 May, and a 1st in Box N. 5. planted 3d. June, under the white Mustard seed, which shades it. The orange comes up, pointed like a pin almost white, which shoots up in two or three quick vegetating days like the present from half an inch to an inch and a half quite straight—turns to a deep green, opens at the point and spreads out two Circular or oval seed leaves, spoon-formed, from which shoots out a long Orange-leaf proper— There oftentimes come up two stems, one shorter than the other, from the same seed— The difference in the rapidity of growth of plants of the same kind is a puzzle. I rode this morning to the rock— Thence went in the boat to the channel of the river—plunged in, swam 15 minutes and returned to the Rock. Rode to the Capitol. Found Mr. Foy at his house— With him I inspected the border and walk to be carried round the west side of the Capitol, and saw that as now making they were too narrow— After breakfast General Porter called with a long Letter from Jacob Radcliff of New-York recommending a secret Negotiation for a commercial Treaty with the Ottoman Porte.— The General enquired if I had assigned the internal improvement surveys to the several Departments— Not yet— George M. Bourne came and renewed his solicitation for employment— He was for a few days employed by Mr E. Everett as a Secretary, and then dismissed with a warm recommendation to me— Mr Brooks of Hingham called. He is to preach here two or three Sundays at the Unitarian Church— Mr Cutts the Comptroller introduced Mr Nye, who comes from New-Orleans to solicit the appointment of Surveyor of that Port, vacant by the death of Mr Emerson— Mr Post, the Chaplain to the House of Representatives, introduced a Mr Salmons, an Englishman, who informed me he had been many years a Clerk in the Banking House of Smith Payne and Smith, London— But he has two Sons who have been settled these ten years at Cincinnati in the State of Ohio— One of them was now with him— He said they were doing well— And he had come to live with them, and pass the remainder of his days in this Country— Mr Gales and Mr Coxe, the Mayors of Washington and Georgetown, came as a Committee from the Corporations of the District, to say that they had determined first to break ground upon the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal on the fourth of July—next Friday— They were charged to invite my attendance, and that I would give the first stroke of the Spade, with both which requests I told them I should with great pleasure comply. They said they proposed to go from Georgetown in Steam-boats to the place where the work is to be commenced, in the State of Maryland, near the Bridge of the Little Falls. They propose to go from Georgetown, at six O’Clock in the Morning, and Mr Gales thought it would
be all over so that we should be back here by ten— Mr Coxe thought it would absorb the greatest part of the day. It makes a question whether the usual reception of Company at the President’s house can take place; the final determination of which was postponed— Mrs Clark and her daughter Susan came here; and Thomas J. Hellen from the College— Mr Foy came to look at my Nursery, and saw where the two Horses did the damage. I had desired him to caution his workman to keep out these animals and the cattle, which are as deadly to all plantations of trees as the scorching winds of the desert. We viewed the Oaks of which we had sowed the Acorns last November in the front yard— More than thirty of them had come up, perfectly well— But the horses and cows, and even Swine have access there; and they have trampled and cropped away three fourths of them already. I spent part of this Evening at writing.
29. IV:30. Sunday— Sun rose 4:43. Chronometer down— Bath. west side of the River.

I went with my Son John, Thomas J. Hellen, and Antoine in the Boat across the river and swam there ten minutes. Landed at the spot where on the of June 1825 I reached the shore after having swamped in the middle of the river— I attended the morning service at the Roman Catholic Church, and heard Mr Harold from Philadelphia— He preached from the 3d. Chapter of Acts—the miraculous restoration of the lame man by Peter and John— The connection between the text and the Discourse was not very apparent— The preacher had written notes, but made not frequent use of them. The indispensable necessity of faith was the theme, with an occasional admission of the necessity also of good works— The composition and the delivery of this person were very good; making allowance for a certain dogmatism, natural enough to the minister of an infallible Church. The sermon was argumentative, but the statement of the adversary argument was somewhat contemptuous and scornful— Another Priest read the prayers and took the communion— Part of the Music performed was Watts’s 100th. Psalm. In the Evening, at the Unitarian Church I heard Mr Brooks, from Matthew 6.10. “Thy kingdom come”— There was a meekness in the manner of Mr Brooks which contrasted with the peremptory tone of Mr Harold— The weather was sultry through the day, with occasional thunder and fresh breezes—one sudden and terrific thunder bolt fell near the house; perhaps in the river. There appeared in Seedling box N. 4. Tangier Oranges 6. 7. 8 planted 15 May— a 3d. in Pot N. 4. planted 3. June, and 2. Oranges in Tumbler N. 4. planted the 15th. of this Month—since which this is only the 14th. day— This must be nearly the shortest possible time for the shoot to appear from an orange seed—to which the midsummer heat, the frequent watering, and the lodging of the seed barely beneath the surface of the ground, all contributed. Fresh orange seeds are the easiest of plants to raise; and besides those that I have lost by drowning, there are now near twenty up in my Pots and boxes, all of which have appeared since the 12th. of this Month— There appears this afternoon in seedling Box N. 4. a whitish shoot pointed like a Sail Needle— I think it one of the date Stones, planted 15. May— As for Cherries Apricots, Plums, Strawberries, Raspberries, Currants, Gooseberries and all the small seeded fruits, I begin to despair of ever raising them in Pots or boxes. The Apple and Peach grow in the garden beds, about twice as fast as they do in Pots. The white Mustard seed in the garden bed is two feet and a half high, in full blossom and going to seed— That in my box N. 5 is none higher than a foot, just beginning to blossom, and the stems all so weak at the root that they cannot stand straight—perhaps because I left the seeds on the surface of the ground to take root of themselves— The quantity of water to be supplied from day to day to the plants in the pots and boxes is a perplexity— When to shelter them from the Sun is another.
30. IV: Monday. Sun-rose 4:43.— Ride and Swim— Capitol— Persico.

The eighth day in succession of my river baths— I rode to the rock; swam 15 Minutes, and then rode to the Navy-yard— Overtaken by a shower, near the Capitol, and took shelter under one of the Arches— Found Mr Persico the Italian Sculptor there; and went up to view his work at the Pediment, of which I furnished him the design— He is now upon the last figure—Hope; and thus far his execution is very satisfactory— His Eagle had been indifferent in the drawing; better, but not good in the model— In the work itself, it is the pouncing bird— He called my attention to the anchor, and said I had told him the anchor of his model was a dutch Anchor. He had therefore gone to Commodore Tingey and taken for his model a true Anchor of a Ship of War— And now said he, whenever a Sailor looks at this Pediment, he will say, how exact the Anchor is! He said he should paint the Scales in the hand of Justice white. They must be painted to prevent their taking the rain, making verdigrease and dropping it upon the Stone figures. He says he expects to finish the work in about two Months— Judge Macomb of Florida, was here, to solicit that a certain grant to Alexander Macomb, father of the General, made by an Act of Congress passed at the last Session of Congress might be detained at the Treasury—for satisfaction of a claim which he judge Macomb has in right of his father, against old Alexander Macomb’s Estate. He said an injunction had issued from the Circuit Court to the Secretary of the Treasury, not to make the payment, but Mr Rush had told him he should disregard the injunction— Judge Macomb that his only resource for recovering any part of his claim, was to obtain it from this grant; and asked my interposition with the Secretary of the Treasury— I promised to converse with him concerning it— Coll. Thomas the late appointed Suttler was here, with gossiping talk of an hour and a half— General Porter came and introduced an old man named Stewart, from the Western part of New-York, a Revolutionary Officer who served through the whole War, and who took the opportunity of the grant made to him at the last Session of Congress, to pay a visit to the City— Mr Andrew Stewart the member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, likewise called— He has been chosen one of the Directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company, and comes to attend their Meetings. Major Delafield called to take leave and brought back General Porter’s Report upon his difference with the British Commissioner on the 7th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— He spoke again of the necessity of a reply to the disingenuous misrepresentations of Mr Barclay’s Report, and said he would prepare it on his return to New-York. He also offered his services for any further public employment to which he may be deemed competent. Mr Bouligny the Senator from Louisiana, brought several Letters recommending a Mr Brainard for the recently vacated office of Surveyor of the Port of New-Orleans; and he requested that the appointment might be deferred for a few days to give time for all the candidates to present their respective claims— I received shortly before dinner a note from Marshal Ringgold with a Letter from J. S. Skinner, the Postmaster at Baltimore, informing him that Mr Monroe, had spent the day yesterday with Mr Charles Carroll of Carrollton, and would be here this afternoon— He came and spent an hour with me in the Evening, and promised to dine with me to-morrow. He has left Mrs Monroe with her daughter Mrs Gouverneur near New-York, where she is to pass the Summer. We conversed upon indifferent topics, and upon European Politics; without touching upon the present state of our own affairs, or the convulsive agitation of the public mind, at the approach of the Presidential election— He is going to attend a Meeting of the Visitors of the University of Virginia.
I planted 12. Orange seeds in Tumbler N. 2. adding to it a little fresh earth— It is the same where a Tamarind, two grapes and 9 Oranges, after promising vegetation all successively died of dropsy. One of the two Oranges which came up yesterday in Tumbler N. 4. died this day from the same cause. A 9th. Tangier Orange came up in Box N. 4. A first in Pot N. 3. planted 3. June—a 3d. in Tumbler N. 4. coming out of the seed— The white, Sail needle shoot in box N. 4. remains as yesterday

Day. I rise at the average of quarter past four— Sometimes write an hour or two, but more frequently devote the morning to exercise and idle occupation. Watching the Plants in my Pots and boxes— Visiting the garden— Reading Evelyn’s Silva— Riding from eight to fourteen miles on horse-back, or swimming from a quarter to half an hour in the Potowmack— Breakfast between nine and ten— Receive visitors, transact business, and write at intervals, and read newspapers public documents and despatches till between five and six when we dine— Visit my Nursery, and make trivial observations upon the vegetation of trees till dark— Repose in torpid inaction from one to two hours— Write, from one to two more—and between 11. and midnight, retire to bed.
